Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a dangerous step towards censorship and totalitarianism.
The terms 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are vague and open to broad interpretation.
The bill exempts government communications from being labeled as misinformation, which is seen as Orwellian.
ACMA's judgment in determining misinformation is questioned, citing past examples during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The legislation could suppress political debate and dissenting views, particularly on foreign policy.
The bill is perceived as a tool for intelligence agencies to enforce social media censorship.
Notable Quotes: The ACP believes that this law is another dangerous lurch down the path to totalitarianism which all Australians should oppose.
The fact that the bill explicitly exempts any government communication, of any level of government, from being considered misinformation or disinformation, shows how Orwellian this law will be.
Regulating truth on social media will not protect democracy, it will suppress it.
